story:
Quality Barware for Craft Cocktails

As artists, foodies, and cocktail lovers, we enjoy not only drinking a good cocktail, but the process of making one. When we started out with cocktails years ago, we used a pint glass and a chopstick to stir our first Old Fashioned Cocktail.  Not my proudest moment, but hey - we didn't know any better, and hadn't collected the right tools yet!

In the years since that first Old Fashioned, we've loved improving our cocktail experience with quality tools.  We even went so far as to re-design the barspoon, and successfully funded a crowdfunding campaign in 2014 to have two designs produced (yay!).

We're back to solve problems with two other cocktail tools: The Mixing Glass, used for stirred cocktails, and The Muddler, used for crushing fruit and vegetables, and pressing herbs and aromatics:

A Cocktail Mixing Glass: 

A Mixing Glass is used for stirred drinks as the prepping vessel. Always STIR cocktails when they contain only clear spirits and liqueurs, like the Old Fashioned, Martini, Manhattan, or Sazerac Cocktails. Add your spirits and other ingredients to the Mixing Glass, add ice, and stir to chill and dilute before straining into the glass you're serving in.

A good Mixing Glass makes this stirring and serving experience a really enjoyable one, and guests love it.

PROBLEM: Many of the fine, beautiful mixing glasses we love are very expensive ($45-60), and those that are more economical ($10-20) leave something (sometimes a LOT) to be desired in the design department. 

SOLUTION: We created a Mixing Glass that was stunning to look at, but didn't break the bank. Especially considering the fact that mixing glasses often DO break, it needed to be affordably replaceable.

 

A Hardwood Muddler:

Muddlers are sometimes used in stirred cocktails, like the Old Fashioned when you want to use a fancy sugar cube instead of simple syrup - use the Muddler to crush up sugar and mix it with bitters before adding your bourbon. More often, muddlers are used for shaken cocktails that contain herbs, aromatics, fruits or vegetables.  A Muddler is used to press fresh mint to extract its oils, and to crush cucumber, berries, and other ingredients for shaken cocktails.

It's also an essential bar tool for crushing ice in a lewis bag to make drinks like the Mint Julep Cocktail.   

PROBLEMS: There are a lot of problems with muddlers. Many manufacturers of bar tools throw in a muddler as an afterthought to complete their bar tool offerings. Often they are made of cheap soft wood that dents easily. Quite often (somewhat unbelieveably), they are finished with stains or varnishes, which is a BIG NO NO when you’re working with something you’re about to put in your body. I remember one of the first muddlers we owned looked like a cherry wood muddler, but it was actually a reddish varnish that started chipping off into our cocktails.  

Another muddler design we don't prefer is the meat-tenderizer style – a textured muddle end that macerates indiscriminately. We don't always want to get at the ingredient like a garbage disposal. Mint leaves should never be torn to shreds for a mojito, but pressed lightly to release the oils only.

SOLUTIONS: A nice flat muddler end treats your mint with respect.  It's also large enough that if you're working with a slippery cucumber or strawberry, it won't escape the big, round, crushing effect of this piece of wood. Oh, and it's also a completely natural muddler, finished only with natural mineral oil (appropriate for all wooden kitchen utensils and cutting boards and such).  It's streamlined, sensible, and sexy.

Options: Maple ($15) and Ebony ($55).  

 

What you Contribute:

 

PHASE 1:

We are excited that we were able to make our first goal for our crowdfunding campaign of $10,000 in order to pay for the absolute essentials to bring the Mixing Glass to life!  This first batch of funds will be taking care of the following:

  • First Production run of the Mixing Glass
  • Packaging and Shipping from the factory to us (and then from us to you)
  • Purchase of a Lathe and tooling for long-term set up for making Muddlers
  • Purchase of initial wood to make Maple and Ebony Muddlers

However, that's not all that's needed in order to really breathe life into these tools! 

PHASE 2 (This is You!):

We have needs that continue past the first round of production, and this is where funds from current pre-sales are going.  You will be a BIG part of making sure we can continue to make these tools!

  • $5,000 for Ebony Wood Stores - because Ebony is so very expensive, we have been purchasing only enough wood to make orders as we receive them.  This is a lean way to do it, in theory, except we're running out of wood here in San Diego - the rest of it is in Cameroon (that's in Africa).  That wood arrives by container ship every 4-6 months, so in order to make sure we have enough for this year (and Christmas next year), we need to place one or two large orders. $5,000 will get us part of the way there - the more we can gather, the more available these beautiful pieces will be.
  • $500 for Ebony & Maple Wood STORAGE - Now that we are working with wood on a larger scale, we need a bit of equipment to properly dry and cure that wood, and store it until it's ready to use. We need a storage shed and a big fan.
  • $2500 for Marketing the Mixing Glass - We have a huge fan base among bartenders.  They would LOVE to have this Mixing Glass in their bars, and we mostly designed it at this price point for them.  However, getting the word out to them, (and especially to the distribution companies that supply their restaurants and bars with tools) is difficult. We need to get some marketing materials together, and get in front of the right people, which could mean going to trade shows / conferences.  Considering a booth at a trade show usually costs around $2K by itself, the more funds we can gather in this department, the more widely distributed the glass will be.

Social Forestry & The Ebony Story

Ebony is a beautiful, naturally dark, dense hardwood. Ebony is strong. Ebony is rare. Ebony is highly desired – and a threatened wood species. 

Ebony has a long history of use, dating back to ancient Egypt. Because of its density, it is one of the strongest woods – it is the only wood that is dense enough to sink in water! However, due to high demand and unsustainable harvesting practices, there just isn’t that much Ebony left in the world. Every country (except one) that used to export ebony has either harvested all of it, or is protecting what little is left. Pete Lowry, ebony and rosewood expert at the Missouri Botanical Garden, calls the Madagascar ebony wood trade the "equivalent of Africa's blood diamonds."

So… why are we making an Ebony muddler?  

We have another story to tell about Ebony – and it starts in Cameroon, the last place in the world where Ebony can still be legally obtained. Most legal ebony is used these days in the music industry – for fingerboards, pegs, picks, and other small parts. However, not all of the ebony that comes to the instrument factories is exactly what they need - it’s too short for a fingerboard, or has a wormhole in it, or some other minor imperfection.

We’ve partnered with Taylor Guitars here in San Diego to make use of the ebony they’ve acquired that cannot be used for guitar making. We’re really excited about this relationship, because it’s a way for us to put into practice in a sustainable way the philosophy of “using the whole pig,” if you will – not wasting a precious resource that is valuable and scarce. In addition, by being an end-user of legal, secondary ebony wood stock, we’ll be supporting the sustainability efforts of ebony growers in Cameroon.  

Here’s an incredible clip of Bob Taylor explaining the ebony wood crisis, and what he and his team are doing to support sustainable harvesting practices in Cameroon.  Video used courtesy of Taylor Guitars.

We are so pleased to be a part of this story!

Our Design Philosophy

  • Quality - with so many corners being cut in manufacturing today, our goal is to bring a standard of quality to our tools that takes us back to the era of the 40's and 50's, when products were built to last. This era also contributes to our design aesthetics, because mid-century tools were as beautiful and classic as they were sturdy.

  • Beauty - because we're artists, aesthetic design is crucial to us.  We will not design ugly tools, no matter how functional they are.

  • Originality - again, probably because we're artists, and we have a great deal of artistic integrity.  We are not interested in creating something that already exists, so we consider innovation in every product we design.

Not all products require the same kind of innovation - with our cocktail spoons, we addressed issues with functionality and longevity.  With our mixing glass, we've addressed issues of price point and accessibility to a beautiful glass. We're making a muddler the way it should be - strong, natural, and firm. We're making the first readily available Ebony Muddler - using wood so dense that it's nearly impregnable to liquid, with a handle that will give the most amazing user experience.

Design Process & Product Details

Mixing Glass Design

FUNCTION - Gorgeous aesthetics aside, from a functionality standpoint, this Mixing Glass is incredible! We've used it ourselves, it's been used by bartenders, has spent time in several high volume bars, and we've gotten great feedback.  Some highlights are:

  • Feels very natural (effortless even) when stirring with a barspoon - it's a good diameter for the mechanics of barspoon use and the spoon flows like butter around the inside of the glass
  • Weighted Bottom - feels great! It's heavier than a tin or a Pyrex glass so it stays where you put it, which makes it less likely to slide around and fall off the bar.
  • Walls of the glass are a good thickness (4 mm) - feels sturdy, but not overdone. Thinner glass means cocktails chill more quickly.
  • The top rim of the glass is nice and thin (as thick as the walls) - so no unsightly bulging.
  • This glass fits a lot of liquid for its size.  It is in no way oversized in your hand, measuring about 3.5 inches (9 cm) in diameter, but has plenty of room inside - it comes in at a whopping 24 oz, or about 700 ml.
  • Fits really nicely in the hand when straining - not too big (or heavy) to handle
  • Fits a Hawthorne strainer like a glove

AESTHETICS - We've gotten a lot of "WOW" moments from folks who love mixing glasses when we show them this one. Here's an overview of some of the aesthetic design features:

  • Antique hammered glass finish - we wanted something different than some of the popular cut glass designs out there today, so we opted for one like hammered glass. It’s subtle, provides texture, and feels natural and organic, like raindrops, leaves, or ripples in a lake. It reflects light incredibly, and makes any cocktail come alive.  
  • Spout design - small and dainty, not something that looks like a giant, unsightly upside down nose:

  • Weighted Bottom - because it just feels good and solid when you set it down, and it stays where you put it.  It reminds us of those nice Old Fashioned Glasses used in Madmen... there's just something about a beautiful slab of glass...
  • Seam v. Seamless - For those of you that own a few mixing glasses already, you may be aware that some mixing glasses are seamed, and some are seamless. The seam does not impact performance, but it costs more to eliminate it, because it's a different manufacturing process. To keep our costs low, and therefore to keep the price point at a reasonable place, this mixing glass does have seams. However, the texture on the glass makes those seams a lot less noticeable, and we think it’s worked wonderfully. So wonderfully, in fact, that we found them incredibly difficult to photograph!

Maple Muddler Design: 

We designed our Muddler out of solid, dense maple wood, with a nice big flat muddle end. It measures 10" long, with a 3/4" diameter on the small end, and a 1-3/8" diameter on the large end. Some smaller diameter muddlers allow a stubborn strawberry or slippery cucumber to get away too quickly – you can really pin them down with this one. 

It’s got a straight, simple design which just looks amazing and makes it aerodynamically easy to clean quickly. And it contains no stains or varnishes (those can flake off into your cocktail!) - it’s finished with natural mineral oil only. We recommend periodically applying mineral oil as a maintenance process, which is recommended for all wooden kitchen tools as a life-extending measure.

Since this muddler is made from natural wood, variations and markings in grain patterns are guaranteed - each Muddler is completely unique!

Ebony Muddler Design: 

Very similar in diameter to our Maple Muddle, the Ebony Muddler also features a sophisticated, ergonomically satisfying handle. It’s quite lovely, and makes grasping a very gratifying experience.

Our Ebony Muddlers have no stain or finish. Ebony is so dense that sanding and polishing are all the finish it needs. These muddlers are so beautiful and so durable that they will easily become treasured heritage pieces in your bar collection.

A Note on Color: Ebony has a reputation as being pure black, but that’s not how all ebony is. If you watched the video of Bob Taylor (above) shedding light on ebony harvesting practices, you’ll have learned that only about 1 in every 10 ebony trees has a solid black core. The only way to know if an ebony tree was solid black in the middle was to chop down trees until you found one. 

Rather than continue this grossly unsustainable practice of wasteful harvesting in order to supply ebony consumers with pure black wood, all 10 trees are now harvested and supplied to end users. This means that 1) we won’t run out of ebony, and 2) the ebony that is now used today has color in it.  

And it’s beautiful! Swirls and fades of grey and blonde add character and a completely unique aesthetic to each muddler we make. So please embrace this new era of ebony, and celebrate the color of the wood with us!

The Aero and Wingman Cocktail Spoons

Missed our first crowdfunding campaign?  These spoons were the result.  The Mixing Glass and Muddlers pair perfectly with these beauties.  You don't have to wait if you want to buy one of these - they are available on our website at www.standardspoon.com, But we do have one Perk that includes both spoons - the Cocktailian Benefactor!

The Aero Cocktail Spoon (top) and Wingman Spinning Cocktail Spoon (below)

Here's a little description of the spoons; for more details, Visit our Website.

Aero Cocktail Spoon: 

While most straight-handled bar spoons are tacked together with a weak weld and often break, ours is fused into one piece for a seamless design.  Its slim profile is easy to insert around the ice in a mixing glass, and its aerodynamic body is great for near-friction-less stirring (perfect for left-handed use too). The bowl of the spoon holds 1/8 oz of liquid, including the meniscus. The weighted end provides for a beautifully balanced bar spoon, something that feels like a tool, not a toy.

Wingman Cocktail Spoon: 

For bartenders, this spoon requires less hand and wrist motion, improves consistency of dilution (especially when stirring two drinks at once), and decreases the concentration required in a high volume setting. This is a go-to spoon for bartenders dealing with occupational injuries or wrist strain. For the home cocktail enthusiast or beginning bartender, this swivel spoon is the easiest way to stir a drink. The bowl of the spoon holds 1/8 oz of liquid, including the meniscus.

 

Cocobolo Muddlers

Wait... What?! 

You may have noticed that the Cocktailian Benefactor Perk includes a special muddler we snuck in for generous backers.  We JUST received a very limited supply of Cocobolo; and we have enough left to make only 5 Muddlers.  Cocobolo is a tropical hardwood from Central America, and is known for its incredible orange and reddish-brown grain.  

We'll be turning some of those on the lathe this week and hope to post some finished photos soon, but until then, here's a peek at the raw wood stock we have on hand:

 

Cocktail Club Membership:

Standard Spoon isn't some big anonymous brand - we're Rachel Eva and Shawn Michael.  We put ourselves into our brand, and when you get bar tools - you get us.  And Shawn's wry sense of humor. And a thing we call Storytime.

When you become a backer of one of our projects, you get access not only to a batch of new tools, but behind-the-scenes details, process photos, moments of inspiration and angst - it's like your own creator-designer-manufacturer reality show. We're even going to go unscripted... LIVE.

So if you want to be a part of something real, authentic, and hilarious, it's time to hop on the bus and become a backer. You can be a part of the story by pledging just $7 - that's all it takes to join the club!

Production Timeline

We produced our first batch of Ebony Muddlers in December 2016 and shipped them out to early backers who pledged via our Kickstarter Campaign.  As of January 2017, we are upgrading some of our tools to create greater efficiencies in the workshop, and will be back to Ebony Muddler Making this month.  We're fulfilling orders for Ebony Muddlers in the order they are received, and since they are a bit time-intensive (that ebony wood is so dense!), we're estimating a 1-2 month waiting period after you place your order.   We will run out of Ebony stock that's here in San Diego probably mid-2017, and then will have to source it from Cameroon, which will take some time to ship, dry, and make - so order early!  Here's a shot of Shawn in the workshop producing the Ebony Muddlers:

Prior to bringing this campaign to you, we found a glass factory overseas, and paid for tooling to have a production sample made, so we would know EXACTLY what we'd be getting.

Since we met our first round of funding, we placed our production order with the factory in December, and have word that the factory has begun production! We are checking in with them periodically about Quality Control during this process.  Since Chinese New Year is just around the corner (when all of China effectively shuts down for several weeks to celebrate), we probably won't take delivery of the Mixing Glasses until March or April.  

We've set a conservative delivery timeline of May for all Mixing Glasses to allow for an internal quality inspection here in San Diego, and then packaging and getting them all out to those of you who pre-order.  All the photos of the Mixing Glass here, and in the video, are our production samples from the factory!

Who We Are

We are Shawn Michael and Rachel Eva, a creative team also known as Work of My Hands. We are artists and designers, and love quality made goods. We've successfully managed three crowdfunding Campaigns: Electricity in Art: Sculptural Lighting (2012),  Standard Spoon for Craft Cocktails (2014), and our just-recently completed initial $10K for this project.

You can explore more about our business, our tools, and our approach to projects on our website and blog: standardspoon.com

 

A Note on Processing and Shipping:

We offered holiday shipping for Christmas 2016 to the first backers of our project. Now that the holidays have come and gone, Maple and Ebony Muddlers, as well as barspoons will ship as we can get to them after fulfilling orders we've already received. Estimated processing time is 1-4 weeks from placing your order for these items, as some may need to be manufactured on demand during this start-up manufacturing phase.  Thanks for your understanding!
story_txt:
Quality Barware for Craft CocktailsAs artists, foodies, and cocktail lovers, we enjoy not only drinking a good cocktail, but the process of making one. When we started out with cocktails years ago, we used a pint glass and a chopstick to stir our first Old Fashioned Cocktail.  Not my proudest moment, but hey - we didn't know any better, and hadn't collected the right tools yet!In the years since that first Old Fashioned, we've loved improving our cocktail experience with quality tools.  We even went so far as to re-design the barspoon, and successfully funded a crowdfunding campaign in 2014 to have two designs produced (yay!).We're back to solve problems with two other cocktail tools: The Mixing Glass, used for stirred cocktails, and The Muddler, used for crushing fruit and vegetables, and pressing herbs and aromatics:A Cocktail Mixing Glass: A Mixing Glass is used for stirred drinks as the prepping vessel. Always STIR cocktails when they contain only clear spirits and liqueurs, like the Old Fashioned, Martini, Manhattan, or Sazerac Cocktails. Add your spirits and other ingredients to the Mixing Glass, add ice, and stir to chill and dilute before straining into the glass you're serving in.A good Mixing Glass makes this stirring and serving experience a really enjoyable one, and guests love it.PROBLEM: Many of the fine, beautiful mixing glasses we love are very expensive ($45-60), and those that are more economical ($10-20) leave something (sometimes a LOT) to be desired in the design department. SOLUTION: We created a Mixing Glass that was stunning to look at, but didn't break the bank. Especially considering the fact that mixing glasses often DO break, it needed to be affordably replaceable. A Hardwood Muddler:Muddlers are sometimes used in stirred cocktails, like the Old Fashioned when you want to use a fancy sugar cube instead of simple syrup - use the Muddler to crush up sugar and mix it with bitters before adding your bourbon. More often, muddlers are used for shaken cocktails that contain herbs, aromatics, fruits or vegetables.  A Muddler is used to press fresh mint to extract its oils, and to crush cucumber, berries, and other ingredients for shaken cocktails.It's also an essential bar tool for crushing ice in a lewis bag to make drinks like the Mint Julep Cocktail.   PROBLEMS: There are a lot of problems with muddlers. Many manufacturers of bar tools throw in a muddler as an afterthought to complete their bar tool offerings. Often they are made of cheap soft wood that dents easily. Quite often (somewhat unbelieveably), they are finished with stains or varnishes, which is a BIG NO NO when you’re working with something you’re about to put in your body. I remember one of the first muddlers we owned looked like a cherry wood muddler, but it was actually a reddish varnish that started chipping off into our cocktails.  Another muddler design we don't prefer is the meat-tenderizer style – a textured muddle end that macerates indiscriminately. We don't always want to get at the ingredient like a garbage disposal. Mint leaves should never be torn to shreds for a mojito, but pressed lightly to release the oils only.SOLUTIONS: A nice flat muddler end treats your mint with respect.  It's also large enough that if you're working with a slippery cucumber or strawberry, it won't escape the big, round, crushing effect of this piece of wood. Oh, and it's also a completely natural muddler, finished only with natural mineral oil (appropriate for all wooden kitchen utensils and cutting boards and such).  It's streamlined, sensible, and sexy.Options: Maple ($15) and Ebony ($55).   What you Contribute: PHASE 1:We are excited that we were able to make our first goal for our crowdfunding campaign of $10,000 in order to pay for the absolute essentials to bring the Mixing Glass to life!  This first batch of funds will be taking care of the following:
First Production run of the Mixing Glass
Packaging and Shipping from the factory to us (and then from us to you)
Purchase of a Lathe and tooling for long-term set up for making Muddlers
Purchase of initial wood to make Maple and Ebony Muddlers
However, that's not all that's needed in order to really breathe life into these tools! PHASE 2 (This is You!):We have needs that continue past the first round of production, and this is where funds from current pre-sales are going.  You will be a BIG part of making sure we can continue to make these tools!
$5,000 for Ebony Wood Stores - because Ebony is so very expensive, we have been purchasing only enough wood to make orders as we receive them.  This is a lean way to do it, in theory, except we're running out of wood here in San Diego - the rest of it is in Cameroon (that's in Africa).  That wood arrives by container ship every 4-6 months, so in order to make sure we have enough for this year (and Christmas next year), we need to place one or two large orders. $5,000 will get us part of the way there - the more we can gather, the more available these beautiful pieces will be.
$500 for Ebony & Maple Wood STORAGE - Now that we are working with wood on a larger scale, we need a bit of equipment to properly dry and cure that wood, and store it until it's ready to use. We need a storage shed and a big fan.
$2500 for Marketing the Mixing Glass - We have a huge fan base among bartenders.  They would LOVE to have this Mixing Glass in their bars, and we mostly designed it at this price point for them.  However, getting the word out to them, (and especially to the distribution companies that supply their restaurants and bars with tools) is difficult. We need to get some marketing materials together, and get in front of the right people, which could mean going to trade shows / conferences.  Considering a booth at a trade show usually costs around $2K by itself, the more funds we can gather in this department, the more widely distributed the glass will be.
Social Forestry & The Ebony StoryEbony is a beautiful, naturally dark, dense hardwood. Ebony is strong. Ebony is rare. Ebony is highly desired – and a threatened wood species. Ebony has a long history of use, dating back to ancient Egypt. Because of its density, it is one of the strongest woods – it is the only wood that is dense enough to sink in water! However, due to high demand and unsustainable harvesting practices, there just isn’t that much Ebony left in the world. Every country (except one) that used to export ebony has either harvested all of it, or is protecting what little is left. Pete Lowry, ebony and rosewood expert at the Missouri Botanical Garden, calls the Madagascar ebony wood trade the "equivalent of Africa's blood diamonds."So… why are we making an Ebony muddler?  We have another story to tell about Ebony – and it starts in Cameroon, the last place in the world where Ebony can still be legally obtained. Most legal ebony is used these days in the music industry – for fingerboards, pegs, picks, and other small parts. However, not all of the ebony that comes to the instrument factories is exactly what they need - it’s too short for a fingerboard, or has a wormhole in it, or some other minor imperfection.We’ve partnered with Taylor Guitars here in San Diego to make use of the ebony they’ve acquired that cannot be used for guitar making. We’re really excited about this relationship, because it’s a way for us to put into practice in a sustainable way the philosophy of “using the whole pig,” if you will – not wasting a precious resource that is valuable and scarce. In addition, by being an end-user of legal, secondary ebony wood stock, we’ll be supporting the sustainability efforts of ebony growers in Cameroon.  Here’s an incredible clip of Bob Taylor explaining the ebony wood crisis, and what he and his team are doing to support sustainable harvesting practices in Cameroon.  Video used courtesy of Taylor Guitars.

We are so pleased to be a part of this story!
Our Design Philosophy
Quality - with so many corners being cut in manufacturing today, our goal is to bring a standard of quality to our tools that takes us back to the era of the 40's and 50's, when products were built to last. This era also contributes to our design aesthetics, because mid-century tools were as beautiful and classic as they were sturdy.
Beauty - because we're artists, aesthetic design is crucial to us.  We will not design ugly tools, no matter how functional they are.
Originality - again, probably because we're artists, and we have a great deal of artistic integrity.  We are not interested in creating something that already exists, so we consider innovation in every product we design.
Not all products require the same kind of innovation - with our cocktail spoons, we addressed issues with functionality and longevity.  With our mixing glass, we've addressed issues of price point and accessibility to a beautiful glass. We're making a muddler the way it should be - strong, natural, and firm. We're making the first readily available Ebony Muddler - using wood so dense that it's nearly impregnable to liquid, with a handle that will give the most amazing user experience.Design Process & Product DetailsMixing Glass DesignFUNCTION - Gorgeous aesthetics aside, from a functionality standpoint, this Mixing Glass is incredible! We've used it ourselves, it's been used by bartenders, has spent time in several high volume bars, and we've gotten great feedback.  Some highlights are:
Feels very natural (effortless even) when stirring with a barspoon - it's a good diameter for the mechanics of barspoon use and the spoon flows like butter around the inside of the glass
Weighted Bottom - feels great! It's heavier than a tin or a Pyrex glass so it stays where you put it, which makes it less likely to slide around and fall off the bar.
Walls of the glass are a good thickness (4 mm) - feels sturdy, but not overdone. Thinner glass means cocktails chill more quickly.
The top rim of the glass is nice and thin (as thick as the walls) - so no unsightly bulging.
This glass fits a lot of liquid for its size.  It is in no way oversized in your hand, measuring about 3.5 inches (9 cm) in diameter, but has plenty of room inside - it comes in at a whopping 24 oz, or about 700 ml.
Fits really nicely in the hand when straining - not too big (or heavy) to handle
Fits a Hawthorne strainer like a glove
AESTHETICS - We've gotten a lot of "WOW" moments from folks who love mixing glasses when we show them this one. Here's an overview of some of the aesthetic design features:
Antique hammered glass finish - we wanted something different than some of the popular cut glass designs out there today, so we opted for one like hammered glass. It’s subtle, provides texture, and feels natural and organic, like raindrops, leaves, or ripples in a lake. It reflects light incredibly, and makes any cocktail come alive.  
Spout design - small and dainty, not something that looks like a giant, unsightly upside down nose:

Weighted Bottom - because it just feels good and solid when you set it down, and it stays where you put it.  It reminds us of those nice Old Fashioned Glasses used in Madmen... there's just something about a beautiful slab of glass...
Seam v. Seamless - For those of you that own a few mixing glasses already, you may be aware that some mixing glasses are seamed, and some are seamless. The seam does not impact performance, but it costs more to eliminate it, because it's a different manufacturing process. To keep our costs low, and therefore to keep the price point at a reasonable place, this mixing glass does have seams. However, the texture on the glass makes those seams a lot less noticeable, and we think it’s worked wonderfully. So wonderfully, in fact, that we found them incredibly difficult to photograph!
Maple Muddler Design: We designed our Muddler out of solid, dense maple wood, with a nice big flat muddle end. It measures 10" long, with a 3/4" diameter on the small end, and a 1-3/8" diameter on the large end. Some smaller diameter muddlers allow a stubborn strawberry or slippery cucumber to get away too quickly – you can really pin them down with this one. It’s got a straight, simple design which just looks amazing and makes it aerodynamically easy to clean quickly. And it contains no stains or varnishes (those can flake off into your cocktail!) - it’s finished with natural mineral oil only. We recommend periodically applying mineral oil as a maintenance process, which is recommended for all wooden kitchen tools as a life-extending measure.Since this muddler is made from natural wood, variations and markings in grain patterns are guaranteed - each Muddler is completely unique!Ebony Muddler Design: Very similar in diameter to our Maple Muddle, the Ebony Muddler also features a sophisticated, ergonomically satisfying handle. It’s quite lovely, and makes grasping a very gratifying experience.Our Ebony Muddlers have no stain or finish. Ebony is so dense that sanding and polishing are all the finish it needs. These muddlers are so beautiful and so durable that they will easily become treasured heritage pieces in your bar collection.A Note on Color: Ebony has a reputation as being pure black, but that’s not how all ebony is. If you watched the video of Bob Taylor (above) shedding light on ebony harvesting practices, you’ll have learned that only about 1 in every 10 ebony trees has a solid black core. The only way to know if an ebony tree was solid black in the middle was to chop down trees until you found one. Rather than continue this grossly unsustainable practice of wasteful harvesting in order to supply ebony consumers with pure black wood, all 10 trees are now harvested and supplied to end users. This means that 1) we won’t run out of ebony, and 2) the ebony that is now used today has color in it.  And it’s beautiful! Swirls and fades of grey and blonde add character and a completely unique aesthetic to each muddler we make. So please embrace this new era of ebony, and celebrate the color of the wood with us!The Aero and Wingman Cocktail SpoonsMissed our first crowdfunding campaign?  These spoons were the result.  The Mixing Glass and Muddlers pair perfectly with these beauties.  You don't have to wait if you want to buy one of these - they are available on our website at www.standardspoon.com, But we do have one Perk that includes both spoons - the Cocktailian Benefactor!The Aero Cocktail Spoon (top) and Wingman Spinning Cocktail Spoon (below)Here's a little description of the spoons; for more details, Visit our Website.Aero Cocktail Spoon: While most straight-handled bar spoons are tacked together with a weak weld and often break, ours is fused into one piece for a seamless design.  Its slim profile is easy to insert around the ice in a mixing glass, and its aerodynamic body is great for near-friction-less stirring (perfect for left-handed use too). The bowl of the spoon holds 1/8 oz of liquid, including the meniscus. The weighted end provides for a beautifully balanced bar spoon, something that feels like a tool, not a toy.Wingman Cocktail Spoon: For bartenders, this spoon requires less hand and wrist motion, improves consistency of dilution (especially when stirring two drinks at once), and decreases the concentration required in a high volume setting. This is a go-to spoon for bartenders dealing with occupational injuries or wrist strain. For the home cocktail enthusiast or beginning bartender, this swivel spoon is the easiest way to stir a drink. The bowl of the spoon holds 1/8 oz of liquid, including the meniscus. Cocobolo MuddlersWait... What?! You may have noticed that the Cocktailian Benefactor Perk includes a special muddler we snuck in for generous backers.  We JUST received a very limited supply of Cocobolo; and we have enough left to make only 5 Muddlers.  Cocobolo is a tropical hardwood from Central America, and is known for its incredible orange and reddish-brown grain.  We'll be turning some of those on the lathe this week and hope to post some finished photos soon, but until then, here's a peek at the raw wood stock we have on hand: Cocktail Club Membership:Standard Spoon isn't some big anonymous brand - we're Rachel Eva and Shawn Michael.  We put ourselves into our brand, and when you get bar tools - you get us.  And Shawn's wry sense of humor. And a thing we call Storytime.When you become a backer of one of our projects, you get access not only to a batch of new tools, but behind-the-scenes details, process photos, moments of inspiration and angst - it's like your own creator-designer-manufacturer reality show. We're even going to go unscripted... LIVE.So if you want to be a part of something real, authentic, and hilarious, it's time to hop on the bus and become a backer. You can be a part of the story by pledging just $7 - that's all it takes to join the club!Production TimelineWe produced our first batch of Ebony Muddlers in December 2016 and shipped them out to early backers who pledged via our Kickstarter Campaign.  As of January 2017, we are upgrading some of our tools to create greater efficiencies in the workshop, and will be back to Ebony Muddler Making this month.  We're fulfilling orders for Ebony Muddlers in the order they are received, and since they are a bit time-intensive (that ebony wood is so dense!), we're estimating a 1-2 month waiting period after you place your order.   We will run out of Ebony stock that's here in San Diego probably mid-2017, and then will have to source it from Cameroon, which will take some time to ship, dry, and make - so order early!  Here's a shot of Shawn in the workshop producing the Ebony Muddlers:Prior to bringing this campaign to you, we found a glass factory overseas, and paid for tooling to have a production sample made, so we would know EXACTLY what we'd be getting.Since we met our first round of funding, we placed our production order with the factory in December, and have word that the factory has begun production! We are checking in with them periodically about Quality Control during this process.  Since Chinese New Year is just around the corner (when all of China effectively shuts down for several weeks to celebrate), we probably won't take delivery of the Mixing Glasses until March or April.  We've set a conservative delivery timeline of May for all Mixing Glasses to allow for an internal quality inspection here in San Diego, and then packaging and getting them all out to those of you who pre-order.  All the photos of the Mixing Glass here, and in the video, are our production samples from the factory!Who We AreWe are Shawn Michael and Rachel Eva, a creative team also known as Work of My Hands. We are artists and designers, and love quality made goods. We've successfully managed three crowdfunding Campaigns: Electricity in Art: Sculptural Lighting (2012),  Standard Spoon for Craft Cocktails (2014), and our just-recently completed initial $10K for this project.You can explore more about our business, our tools, and our approach to projects on our website and blog: standardspoon.com A Note on Processing and Shipping:We offered holiday shipping for Christmas 2016 to the first backers of our project. Now that the holidays have come and gone, Maple and Ebony Muddlers, as well as barspoons will ship as we can get to them after fulfilling orders we've already received. Estimated processing time is 1-4 weeks from placing your order for these items, as some may need to be manufactured on demand during this start-up manufacturing phase.  Thanks for your understanding!

story:
Spices Reimagined - Organic Spices in Innovative Containers by Five Continent Spices

 

Designed by home-chefs for home-chefs, preserving flavor, shaped for precise use, space minimizing stand, thus ending clutter

 

We are all avid cooks who became frustrated with the mess of our spice cabinets and the poor design of the spice bottles.

 

The Five Continent SpicePuck™ is a better functioning, uniquely shaped spice container with two doors, a stainless steel bottom for durability and to keep spices potent. The hockey puck shape and weight make it feel great in your hand.

The shaker door lets you shake out spices the same way you currently use your glass containers. The large spoon door allows precise and easy access with a measuring spoon. Shake or Spoon - impossible with old-fashioned glass jars. The color of the shaker door lets you easily pick the right spice.

"Shaker door" open

 

"Spoon door" open

 

Cooking demo with Five Continent Spices

 

Keep Your Spices Spicy (Protect & Serve)

The Five Continent SpicePuck’s stainless steel base and solid top protect your valuable organic spices from “potency-reducing” light exposure. Let your SpicePucks serve you where you need them instead of keeping them "far, far away" in a pantry or a kitchen cabinet.

Blank SpicePuck for your own custom spices and herbs

 

High Quality, Organic Spices & Herbs

Of course, we will include high quality, organic spices and herbs that will elevate your cooking. Several of our partners and cooperatives source directly from farmers and growers globally to ensure excellent quality. We prioritize suppliers that produce their spices in ways that are good for growers and the planet. Needless to say, the better the spice, the better your results.

For example, the spices used in the cooking video are certified organic and kosher with the rosemary grown in Morocco, the sage in Italy and the cayenne (30,000 HU) in India.

 

Color-Coded for Easy Identification

The SpicePuck shaker doors will have six different colors to make the identification of organic spices and herbs easier. For example, most herbs will have green doors (i.e. Basil, Bay Laurel, etc.); Curry, Turmeric, etc. will have a yellow door; Cayenne Pepper, Paprika, etc. will have a red door; Mustard, Sesame, etc. will have a tan door; Nutmeg, Caraway, etc. will have a brown door; Black doors are for your custom spices and seasonings.

 

Large Volume – More Spice

It is not obvious, but the SpicePucks are 10-20% bigger than traditional glass containers. We will include more organic spices in the SpicePucks than your average glass bottle can hold.

 

Sustainable Design

The SpicePuck's stainless steel base and the solid top are made to last. After the campaign, we will offer a cost-effective refill baggie to minimize waste.

 

Democratize Spices

Tired of paying different prices for different spices? After the campaign, each spice's list price will be $8.99, regardless of the spice type.

And a refill baggie will cost only $5.99, regardless of the spice type. It will be shipped in a protective pouch. It will also contain more spice than the SpicePuck container will hold itself, so you will have a reserve.

Backers will receive each SpicePuck at the discounted price of $6.99, and each Baggie at $4.99 for all of 2018 and 2019.

 

Find the Right Spice at the Right Time Right Next to where you Cook.

Tired of storing your spices out of reach and then searching through the current mess? The Five Continent Spices stand makes your spices easy to identify, to access, and to return. The compact design frees-up valuable counter space.

Stand A - "circular" counter-top stand

Stand B - "high density" stand for counter-top or cabinet

 

No More Clutter

Current spice containers don't work well for cooks and are old fashioned and uninspiring. If you look around your kitchen, almost everything has seen significant design improvements during the last 20 years, except spices are still a mess. SpicePucks in their stand will help eliminate clutter in your kitchen.

 

Countless Engineering Cycles

 

The Five Continent Spices team spent months refining and perfecting the design of the SpicePuck and the stand. We also thought about how to get the finished product packaged for our backers.

 

What People are Saying

 

 

Five Continent Spices Team

 

Spices are part of the culture on all five continents. Our spices originate from all five continents. The founders' experience spans all five continents. 

As a team, we are very experienced in bringing both, new FMCG and technology products, to market. We draw on our passion for food, cooking, entertaining, design, and our real-world experience in engineering, product development, manufacturing, supply chain management, e-commerce, and support.

 

The Continental European - Erik

Erik used his global business travels to over 60 countries to explore local and unusual food. While Erik attended high school in Berlin, Germany, he worked in a commercial, high-end kitchen, almost convincing himself to become a chef. Ever since he enjoys cooking for friends and family adding dishes and spices from his international travels. His proudest moment was cooking three completely different ducks for a large dinner party.

The British - Neil

Neil left England to discover good food  :-)   He has lived in various locations across the USA, and now resides in Silicon Valley, where he enjoys the wide variety of ethnic dishes on offer. He has also traveled extensively, adding to his exposure to different tastes. His experiences in marketing, engineering, supply chain, and growing new businesses from scratch, are all helping Five Continent Spices.

The East Asian - Dr. Wuby

Having grown up in a suburb of Taiwan, Dr. Wuby prefers delicacies from local eateries and family-style cooking over any fine-dining foods. He prides himself on his lack of Michelin-worthy restaurant experiences and still calls himself a food enthusiast. In his other life, Dr. Wuby is a serial entrepreneur who has over 25 years of experience in product development, e-commerce, web management and inbound marketing strategies. And just for the record, Dr. Wuby makes excellent chicken feet and a killer flan.

The Middle Eastern - Afsaneh

Afsaneh grew up in Persia and always reminisces about home-cooked Persian food and the good old days. She began cooking with her mother when she was 6 and has cooked ever since. After she came to California, she began fusing Persian and Californian cuisine. Afsaneh primarily uses organic ingredients and spices in her creations, most often sourced at local farmers markets. She is in the process of documenting the dishes and recipes passed on by her mother.

The American - Matt

Born and raised in the heart of Silicon Valley, Matt’s love of cooking began in grade school at an early age. From there, he worked his way through high school and college in the restaurant industry starting out as a “shake-boy” at the local Foster’s Freeze and later working in just about every role a restaurant has from busboy to pizza maker, bartender to restaurant manager. With over 15 years experience in working with a wide range of media and channels, he is helping to take Five Continent Spices to the next level.

 

Our Campaign

 

We have been working hard since 2017 to design our products. We have completed the prototyping phase of the Five Continent SpicePuck and their innovative stand. We even finished low quantity pre-production runs to further test the design, manufacturability, and quality. We already selected the suppliers of organic spices and herbs.

The next steps are:

  • Move the product design into large-scale manufacturing (build high capacity molds and tooling)
  • Full-scale manufacturing runs of spice containers
  • Full-scale manufacturing runs of stands
  • Quality Control and Testing of Manufactured Products
  • Ship SpicePucks to the US spice warehouse
  • Assemble, fill, and package SpicePucks
  • Assemble and package stands
  • Ship Perks

 

Timeline

 

How the funds will be used

 

The funds will be used to pay for our production molds and tooling costs as well as the initial inventory required to assemble and ship the kits to you. We promise frequent updates on our progress, at least monthly, though we hope to be even more frequent. We love blogging and posting on social media, so as a backer you should expect many updates with lots of photos and the occasional video. We've already been previewing photos of our solution on our Facebook and Twitter pages. We'll keep updating those with more info, and we suggest you follow us.

 

Why Crowdfunding?

 

Indiegogo is a proven crowdfunding platform with an avid "early adopter" community. We are convinced that this is a great way to tap into the community for feedback and guidance on refining the current products as well as designing our next products. We highly value the Indiegogo community and its role in supporting innovation. We hope that you find the Five Continent Spices idea worthwhile and support us.

 

FAQ's

 

Do you offer refills?

Yes. We offer something we call "baggie." The protective pouch contains enough spices to fill an existing SpicePuck. In other words, more spices than your regular glass jar.

 

How much can you fit into a SpicePuck?

We designed the SpicePucks to be about 10-20% bigger than most normal-sized glass containers. Our Refill baggies will contain more spices and herbs than you would get in grocery store glass containers to take advantage of the bigger volume of the SpicePuck.

 

Can you ship to countries outside of your listed ship-to countries?

Yes. Please select shipping to Europe and contact us about shipping to your country.  So far, we have only researched shipping within the US and to Europe since they have an agreement recognizing the organic certification regardless of where it was issued. Other countries may not allow us to call our products organic. Besides, some countries have very restrictive import controls for food items and may consider spice & herbs to fall into that category. So please connect with us, and we will try our best to ship to you.

 

What materials are the SpicePucks made of?

The bottom is food grade stainless steel and the tops are made of food grade polypropylene carbonate.

 

Will you offer additional individual spices and herbs after the campaign?

Yes, we expect to offer an extensive number of individual spices and herbs after the campaign. We envision to offer the same spice from different locations or different variations (i.e., cayenne pepper comes in a wide range of HU)

 

If I want to store the pucks in my cabinet or a drawer, how can I identify the product?

We will ship the initial kits with a self-adhesive sheet that allows you to put the spice name on the side of the puck. That way, you can identify the spice from the side as well. We expect to design custom holders for cabinets and drawers later this year. We will share our designs with you as soon as we have the first prototypes.

 

What is the footprint & height of the stand and will it fit under my wall cabinet?

The Five Continent Spices footprint of the stand is 8.66 inches (220 millimeters) by 8.66 inches (220 millimeters). The height of the Five Continent Spices stand depends on how many platforms are assembled but should not exceed 12.2 inches (310 millimeters) which should allow it to easily fit on the counter under any wall cabinet. We recommend a max of 5 platforms holding 15 SpicePucks.

 

Why not include pepper or salt in your kits? 

We made a decision not to include salt and pepper for two reasons. The first one is that there are so many different types of peppers and salts out there, it is difficult to select one that will satisfy everyone (black, green, red, white peppers from different countries, regions, and styles – same for salt). The second, more important reason is that we think salt and pepper should be in a grinder (especially pepper) because grinding it to the right size at the right time (i.e., fresh) makes a huge difference. Right now, our SpicePucks do not have grinding capabilities so we felt it would be better not to include them.

 

Please Help Us Get the Word Out

We really appreciate your help with "getting the word out" and growing mindshare for Five Continent Spices:

  • Please promote us to your friends, family, colleagues, and acquaintances that you know are interested in home cooking
  • Please visit and refer our website at www.fivecontinentspices.com
  • Please connect with us through social media and promote and share our updates - we are on LinkedIn, Facebook and Twitter
  • Please use your Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks for listening. We are excited to bring "Spices Reimaged" to people around the world with our Five Continent Spices kits of spices.
story_txt:
Spices Reimagined - Organic Spices in Innovative Containers by Five Continent Spices
 
Designed by home-chefs for home-chefs, preserving flavor, shaped for precise use, space minimizing stand, thus ending clutter
 
We are all avid cooks who became frustrated with the mess of our spice cabinets and the poor design of the spice bottles.

 
The Five Continent SpicePuck™ is a better functioning, uniquely shaped spice container with two doors, a stainless steel bottom for durability and to keep spices potent. The hockey puck shape and weight make it feel great in your hand.
The shaker door lets you shake out spices the same way you currently use your glass containers. The large spoon door allows precise and easy access with a measuring spoon. Shake or Spoon - impossible with old-fashioned glass jars. The color of the shaker door lets you easily pick the right spice.

"Shaker door" open
 

"Spoon door" open
 

Cooking demo with Five Continent Spices
 
Keep Your Spices Spicy (Protect & Serve)
The Five Continent SpicePuck’s stainless steel base and solid top protect your valuable organic spices from “potency-reducing” light exposure. Let your SpicePucks serve you where you need them instead of keeping them "far, far away" in a pantry or a kitchen cabinet.

Blank SpicePuck for your own custom spices and herbs
 
High Quality, Organic Spices & Herbs
Of course, we will include high quality, organic spices and herbs that will elevate your cooking. Several of our partners and cooperatives source directly from farmers and growers globally to ensure excellent quality. We prioritize suppliers that produce their spices in ways that are good for growers and the planet. Needless to say, the better the spice, the better your results.

For example, the spices used in the cooking video are certified organic and kosher with the rosemary grown in Morocco, the sage in Italy and the cayenne (30,000 HU) in India.
 
Color-Coded for Easy Identification
The SpicePuck shaker doors will have six different colors to make the identification of organic spices and herbs easier. For example, most herbs will have green doors (i.e. Basil, Bay Laurel, etc.); Curry, Turmeric, etc. will have a yellow door; Cayenne Pepper, Paprika, etc. will have a red door; Mustard, Sesame, etc. will have a tan door; Nutmeg, Caraway, etc. will have a brown door; Black doors are for your custom spices and seasonings.

 
Large Volume – More Spice
It is not obvious, but the SpicePucks are 10-20% bigger than traditional glass containers. We will include more organic spices in the SpicePucks than your average glass bottle can hold.

 
Sustainable Design
The SpicePuck's stainless steel base and the solid top are made to last. After the campaign, we will offer a cost-effective refill baggie to minimize waste.

 
Democratize Spices
Tired of paying different prices for different spices? After the campaign, each spice's list price will be $8.99, regardless of the spice type.
And a refill baggie will cost only $5.99, regardless of the spice type. It will be shipped in a protective pouch. It will also contain more spice than the SpicePuck container will hold itself, so you will have a reserve.
Backers will receive each SpicePuck at the discounted price of $6.99, and each Baggie at $4.99 for all of 2018 and 2019.
 
Find the Right Spice at the Right Time Right Next to where you Cook.
Tired of storing your spices out of reach and then searching through the current mess? The Five Continent Spices stand makes your spices easy to identify, to access, and to return. The compact design frees-up valuable counter space.

Stand A - "circular" counter-top stand

Stand B - "high density" stand for counter-top or cabinet
 
No More Clutter
Current spice containers don't work well for cooks and are old fashioned and uninspiring. If you look around your kitchen, almost everything has seen significant design improvements during the last 20 years, except spices are still a mess. SpicePucks in their stand will help eliminate clutter in your kitchen.


 
Countless Engineering Cycles
 
The Five Continent Spices team spent months refining and perfecting the design of the SpicePuck and the stand. We also thought about how to get the finished product packaged for our backers.

 
What People are Saying
 

 
Five Continent Spices Team
 
Spices are part of the culture on all five continents. Our spices originate from all five continents. The founders' experience spans all five continents. 
As a team, we are very experienced in bringing both, new FMCG and technology products, to market. We draw on our passion for food, cooking, entertaining, design, and our real-world experience in engineering, product development, manufacturing, supply chain management, e-commerce, and support.

 
The Continental European - Erik
Erik used his global business travels to over 60 countries to explore local and unusual food. While Erik attended high school in Berlin, Germany, he worked in a commercial, high-end kitchen, almost convincing himself to become a chef. Ever since he enjoys cooking for friends and family adding dishes and spices from his international travels. His proudest moment was cooking three completely different ducks for a large dinner party.
The British - Neil
Neil left England to discover good food  :-)   He has lived in various locations across the USA, and now resides in Silicon Valley, where he enjoys the wide variety of ethnic dishes on offer. He has also traveled extensively, adding to his exposure to different tastes. His experiences in marketing, engineering, supply chain, and growing new businesses from scratch, are all helping Five Continent Spices.
The East Asian - Dr. Wuby
Having grown up in a suburb of Taiwan, Dr. Wuby prefers delicacies from local eateries and family-style cooking over any fine-dining foods. He prides himself on his lack of Michelin-worthy restaurant experiences and still calls himself a food enthusiast. In his other life, Dr. Wuby is a serial entrepreneur who has over 25 years of experience in product development, e-commerce, web management and inbound marketing strategies. And just for the record, Dr. Wuby makes excellent chicken feet and a killer flan.
The Middle Eastern - Afsaneh
Afsaneh grew up in Persia and always reminisces about home-cooked Persian food and the good old days. She began cooking with her mother when she was 6 and has cooked ever since. After she came to California, she began fusing Persian and Californian cuisine. Afsaneh primarily uses organic ingredients and spices in her creations, most often sourced at local farmers markets. She is in the process of documenting the dishes and recipes passed on by her mother.
The American - Matt
Born and raised in the heart of Silicon Valley, Matt’s love of cooking began in grade school at an early age. From there, he worked his way through high school and college in the restaurant industry starting out as a “shake-boy” at the local Foster’s Freeze and later working in just about every role a restaurant has from busboy to pizza maker, bartender to restaurant manager. With over 15 years experience in working with a wide range of media and channels, he is helping to take Five Continent Spices to the next level.
 
Our Campaign
 
We have been working hard since 2017 to design our products. We have completed the prototyping phase of the Five Continent SpicePuck and their innovative stand. We even finished low quantity pre-production runs to further test the design, manufacturability, and quality. We already selected the suppliers of organic spices and herbs.
The next steps are:

Move the product design into large-scale manufacturing (build high capacity molds and tooling)
Full-scale manufacturing runs of spice containers
Full-scale manufacturing runs of stands
Quality Control and Testing of Manufactured Products
Ship SpicePucks to the US spice warehouse
Assemble, fill, and package SpicePucks
Assemble and package stands
Ship Perks

 
Timeline

 
How the funds will be used
 
The funds will be used to pay for our production molds and tooling costs as well as the initial inventory required to assemble and ship the kits to you. We promise frequent updates on our progress, at least monthly, though we hope to be even more frequent. We love blogging and posting on social media, so as a backer you should expect many updates with lots of photos and the occasional video. We've already been previewing photos of our solution on our Facebook and Twitter pages. We'll keep updating those with more info, and we suggest you follow us.
 
Why Crowdfunding?
 
Indiegogo is a proven crowdfunding platform with an avid "early adopter" community. We are convinced that this is a great way to tap into the community for feedback and guidance on refining the current products as well as designing our next products. We highly value the Indiegogo community and its role in supporting innovation. We hope that you find the Five Continent Spices idea worthwhile and support us.
 
FAQ's
 
Do you offer refills?
Yes. We offer something we call "baggie." The protective pouch contains enough spices to fill an existing SpicePuck. In other words, more spices than your regular glass jar.
 
How much can you fit into a SpicePuck?
We designed the SpicePucks to be about 10-20% bigger than most normal-sized glass containers. Our Refill baggies will contain more spices and herbs than you would get in grocery store glass containers to take advantage of the bigger volume of the SpicePuck.
 
Can you ship to countries outside of your listed ship-to countries?
Yes. Please select shipping to Europe and contact us about shipping to your country.  So far, we have only researched shipping within the US and to Europe since they have an agreement recognizing the organic certification regardless of where it was issued. Other countries may not allow us to call our products organic. Besides, some countries have very restrictive import controls for food items and may consider spice & herbs to fall into that category. So please connect with us, and we will try our best to ship to you.
 
What materials are the SpicePucks made of?
The bottom is food grade stainless steel and the tops are made of food grade polypropylene carbonate.
 
Will you offer additional individual spices and herbs after the campaign?
Yes, we expect to offer an extensive number of individual spices and herbs after the campaign. We envision to offer the same spice from different locations or different variations (i.e., cayenne pepper comes in a wide range of HU)
 
If I want to store the pucks in my cabinet or a drawer, how can I identify the product?
We will ship the initial kits with a self-adhesive sheet that allows you to put the spice name on the side of the puck. That way, you can identify the spice from the side as well. We expect to design custom holders for cabinets and drawers later this year. We will share our designs with you as soon as we have the first prototypes.
 
What is the footprint & height of the stand and will it fit under my wall cabinet?
The Five Continent Spices footprint of the stand is 8.66 inches (220 millimeters) by 8.66 inches (220 millimeters). The height of the Five Continent Spices stand depends on how many platforms are assembled but should not exceed 12.2 inches (310 millimeters) which should allow it to easily fit on the counter under any wall cabinet. We recommend a max of 5 platforms holding 15 SpicePucks.
 
Why not include pepper or salt in your kits? 
We made a decision not to include salt and pepper for two reasons. The first one is that there are so many different types of peppers and salts out there, it is difficult to select one that will satisfy everyone (black, green, red, white peppers from different countries, regions, and styles – same for salt). The second, more important reason is that we think salt and pepper should be in a grinder (especially pepper) because grinding it to the right size at the right time (i.e., fresh) makes a huge difference. Right now, our SpicePucks do not have grinding capabilities so we felt it would be better not to include them.
 
Please Help Us Get the Word Out
We really appreciate your help with "getting the word out" and growing mindshare for Five Continent Spices:

Please promote us to your friends, family, colleagues, and acquaintances that you know are interested in home cooking
Please visit and refer our website at www.fivecontinentspices.com

Please connect with us through social media and promote and share our updates - we are on LinkedIn, Facebook and Twitter
Please use your Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks for listening. We are excited to bring "Spices Reimaged" to people around the world with our Five Continent Spices kits of spices.

story:
Our Crowdfund Campaign has ended. If you'd like to become a mug club member, you can register at our online store. Tusen Takk!

 

Welcome to Skål Beer Hall!

Before we open our doors this Spring, we are aiming to raise funds to help put the finishing touches on our beer hall and makeup for the series of setbacks and delays we have experienced working through the challenges of an old building in a historic district. Thanks in advance for the support! 

Skål (meaning “Cheers” in Norwegian) Beer Hall is our interpretation of a Viking meadhall. The meadhall was the center of the community – a welcoming spot to gather or to host visitors from afar. It was the hall where stories of adventure, exploration, and new ideas were shared and debated over food and drink. It was filled with cheer.

Our great hall will offer a rotating selection of local craft beer, cider, and mead, regional wine, and specialty cocktails (with emphasis on the Scandinavian favorite - aquavit). We’re looking forward to featuring some of our terrific but hard-to-find local products as well as some Scandinavian imports.

The open kitchen – inspired by the idea of a Viking butcher shop – will feature bar bites and shared plates that explore wild flavors from the woods and sea. Imagine (if you will) gathering near a roaring fire at the edge of a fjord. Here is where you’d find our food. There will be Nordic influences, traditional bar snacks, and a whole lot of meat (but meatballs are unlikely, sorry Grandma)! 

We don’t take ourselves too seriously and neither should you. Come have a beer or three. Order from our kitchen counter and bar. Chat up your bartender. Play a game. Cozy up to the fire. And invite the whole village.

We will be family friendly (for all our little Vikings out there!) in our front section, 21+ in the back. After 8pm, we'll likely be 21+ only. 

We hope to raise a drinking horn and “Skål” together when we open!

Adam & Lexi 

 

About Us

Adam is a veteran of the craft beer industry - managing marketing and visitor center experiences for multiple breweries over the last seven years. Lexi is the chef/owner of Old Ballard Liquor Co, an aquavit distillery and small Nordic cafe in Ballard. 

If you'd like to learn more about our story, please check out some of our early media coverage from The Norwegian American,  Seattle Met (#1), Seattle Met (#2), and MyBallard. 

 

What We Aim to Fund & What You Get

Wow! We're overwhelmed by the support in hitting our goal in less than a month (May 2018). You can continue to contribute. In doing so, we'll be able to bring you an even better experience in our hall! Our fundraising  will go towards the following:

  • Rent and budget overages from construction delays 
  • Long communal beer hall tables and other furniture
  • Large central fireplace
  • Murals, shields, and other decor
  • Specialty glassware (e.g., viking tankards) 
  • Rotisserie for large meats
  • Serving and smallwares 
  • Merchandise to show your love for Skål (t-shirts, mugs/glassware, hats, etc.)

In exchange for your help, we've got a Viking's haul of great perks planned including memberships to our loyalty program and exclusive experiences. Please check out how you can contribute on the right side of this page. 

If you'd like to financially contribute to our campaign in a different way than what we have listed, please send an email to info@skalballard.com. We are open to loan investments or other proposals. Every bit counts!

Note: If you opt for the "Enter Valhalla" level, we will follow up with a form to fill out to relay your Viking name for the wall. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Outside of your contribution, you can help build buzz for us by liking our Facebook page, following us on Instagram, or signing up for our email newsletter. Thanks!

story:
Project Overview:

InterplanetaryFoods is a startup indoor farming company experimenting in ways to grow food on The Moon and Mars. Our goal with the company is to create more sustainable ways of food production on Earth as well as to develop methods of production for future interplanetary travel. We like to say "ad astra" the Latin saying for "to the stars" our thinking is that the best way to create sustainable methods here on Earth is to look towards the stars and experiment in the harshest possible conditions. Currently, we're using our custom-developed Martian regolith, the v1.0mars_analog, to study the process of seed germination and food production on mars environment. Learn more about v1.0mars_analog here: https://www.interplanetaryfoods.com/v1mars

Our Ask:

We are seeking $10,000 in our first crowdfunding round. This funding would go towards the continuing development of the second version of our Mars analog, v2.0mars_analog as well as developing our first lunar analog, v1.0lunar_analog.

Impact:

Continuing the development of our regolith analogs will allow us to make improvements to our Mars Farm and allow us to create a Lunar Farm. The Mars Farm is InterplanetaryFoods' staging ground for growing and producing food on mars. Read more about The Mars Farm: https://www.interplanetaryfoods.com/marsfarm

Other Ways You Can Help:

Share this page, visit our website, follow us, or email us to get in contact. Help us spread the project!

Twitter: https://twitter.com/PlanetaryFoods

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/PlanetaryFoods

Website: https://www.interplanetaryfoods.com

Email: hello@interplanetaryfoods.com

story:
We couldn’t be prouder of the wine we make.

We are bringing California Wine Country directly to Southern California in a comfortable, no-snobs-allowed tasting room. Our wide-ranging fruit sources will allow our customers to get a virtual tour of California vineyards from Sonoma, to Paso Robles, to Santa Ynez and Santa Rita Hills, all without having to make the drive north to wine country. 

Winemaking is all about the grapes. The secret is to get excellent fruit, and then don’t screw it up. So we spend a lot of time and research finding some of the best vineyards from all over California (and our connections from running The Garagiste Festivals certainly don’t hurt). The fruit ain’t cheap, but the quality shows up in the glass. This is the good stuff, and we make it by hand, with love, barrel by barrel.

What We Need & What You Get

Unlike breweries, which can get their product to market in a matter of weeks, wineries have a much longer turn-around time - sometimes over two years between harvest and bottling. We are looking to raise $35,000 to help us put the finishing touches on the Tasting Room, get our 2014 and 2015 barrels into the bottle, take care of several unforeseen, expensive problems that our old building has presented us with, not to mention a break-in and theft of all our tools. We've poured our hearts, souls, and bank accounts into this project for years - now it's time get over the finish line.

You will get special wines - only for our supporters, special access, barrel tastings, parties, swag, and get to hang out at the coolest new wine room in Southern California knowing that you helped make it happen.

The Impact

Our tasting room will give you a place to relax, hang out and enjoy some wine with us. It will also help spread the growing Garagiste micro-winery movement to SoCal, as well as help us to support local music, art, and causes.

Producing the successful Garagiste Festivals in Paso Robles, Santa Ynez, LA, and the Bay Area for the past six years has given us insight, contacts, experience, and customers far beyond many winery start-ups. We've got a great head start and a heck of a track record - now it's time to get this thing wrapped up, open our doors, and start getting the wine to the people!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join our Wine Club! Just visit our website or Facebook page for more info on that.
  • Please forward this info to any wine geeks in your life - we're pretty sure they'll like the wine, at least!

story:
Short Summary

Everyday Gourmet started out as a small natural food store supplier with plant based muffins and cookies.  The passion for plant based foods has grown and grown within the company as well as in the industry, so we now want to have our own cafe that includes all of our favorite healthy (and comfort) foods.  Food is love and social, so we want to bring people together to eat delicious, compassionate food in a really great atmosphere.  Continuing our mail orders and wholesale orders will be an ongoing task.  Adding a face to it with a place for people to congregate is just the icing on the cake.....yea that just happened.

What We Need & What You Get

The break down:

  • We have a lot of start up costs including cosmetic updates, new sign, equipment for smoothies, waffles, pizza, and ice machine and some other kitchen tools.
  • We have special perks for our early contributors including discounts on foods and special goody bags.
  • If we don't reach the goal, the funds will go into reducing our start up costs.

The Impact

The difference your contribution will make:

  • Your pledge goes beyond your belly!  Plant powered foods are better for the environment, people, animals, and our future.
  • You will directly influence the menu...the more money we have to start with, the more equipment we can buy to make all of the delicious foods we'd like o offer.
  • You will immediately be put on our loyalty program that will let you save money every time you come in.

Risks & Challenges

Our idea is to get into a turnkey operation with minimal investment. The funds raised from this project will get us a few more pieces of equipment and maybe help with the first month of operations. The goal is to be low risk and high reward for us and the community (meaning planet). More plant based options benefit everyone every where!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, here's what you can do:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Do so by using the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it. Yay!

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Do so by using the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it. Yay!

story:
Wingopolis

For over 40 years I’ve eaten the chicken wings that I hope many of you will come to want and love just as I did as a kid growing up on the Southside of Chicago. Grandma made the chicken wings and handed me the hot sauce. A love affair was born. Today we call it, “Wingopolis!” There are 14 flavors now! I invite you to come on in to enjoy the fresh, healthy and tasty chicken wings that still use Grandma’s same original hot wings recipe. I've served up almost 3000 orders alone with God.

Peace and Blessings

 

What/Why We Need

Your support can assist in moving forward with things such as:

  • *Efficient equipment
  • *Adding staff to the operation
  • *Sit down area for the customers
  • Ability to provide a beverage with all combos for customers
  • *Being open regular business hours daily: Breakfast, lunch and dinner
  • *Full Point of Sale system
  • *Inventory software to better manage inventory investment
  • Add a Vegan/Vegetarian Menu Options

The Impact

Your contributions can make a big difference in Wingopolis having an opportunity to make improvements for customers. Impacting the communities that we serve with job opportunities. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Everyone knows that there's another "W" out there. But this "W", Wingopolis is the one!

  • By providing quality food products we can become the number one choice for chicken wings
  • Providing excellent and unparalleled customer service will keep guests happy

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute kindly share the campaign with others and ask them to do the same:

  • Kindly get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the tools and gadgets provided by Indiegogo to share this campaign! I'd sincerely appreciate it.

No matter where you are...your city or state, my goal is to be right down the street one day with a, Wingopolis! I look forward to you having the chicken wings that my grandmother first made for me over 40 years ago. As always...Peace and Blessings
